Text: Thursday, 8 March, 1917.

Speaker: NA
Text: RAIDERININDIAN OCEAN.

Speaker: Mr BOYD
Text: The Minister for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Navy asked me to repeat to-day a ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion that I asked yesterday.

Speaker: NA
Text: know i f the Government will make a

Speaker: NA
Text: complete statement regarding the two

Speaker: NA
Text: vessels lost i n the Indian Ocean, so that

Speaker: NA
Text: the public may know the exact facts, and

Speaker: NA
Text: not be misled by rumours which are gra-

Speaker: NA
Text: dually growing worse ?

Speaker: Mr JOSEPH COOK
Text: I am sorry

Speaker: NA
Text: that I have not a definite answer to the

Speaker: NA
Text: question, but I am making inquiries to

Speaker: NA
Text: ascertain i f I can add anything to my

Speaker: NA
Text: statement of yesterday, and when I am

Speaker: NA
Text: able to do so, I shall let the honorable

Speaker: NA
Text: member know the result. I desire to

Speaker: NA
Text: read to the House the following state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment concerning the presence of a raider

Speaker: NA
Text: i n the Indian Ocean-

Speaker: NA
Text: There have been rumours of danger in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Indian Ocean for some days past. To-day

Speaker: NA
Text: definite information has been received that a

Speaker: NA
Text: raider was on February 27th operating on the

Speaker: NA
Text: route between Colombo and Aden. The

Speaker: NA
Text: raider is a large cargo steamer of about 4,000

Speaker: NA
Text: tons register, carrying guns and torpedo tubes.

Speaker: NA
Text: She also carries a seaplane.

Speaker: NA
Text: After operating for a few days on one route

Speaker: NA
Text: it is usual for a raider to disappear for a time,

Speaker: NA
Text: and then to reappear on another route, pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibly in quite another part of the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: Members will thus see that a raid on Austra-

Speaker: NA
Text: lian routes is not impossible, and is a danger

Speaker: NA
Text: against which we must take precautions. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have not, since the early days of the war, since,

Speaker: NA
Text: in fact, the day the Sydney sank the Emden,

Speaker: NA
Text: been threatened quite so directly on the trade

Speaker: NA
Text: routes in these waters. There is, of course,

Speaker: NA
Text: no reason for any panic or at present for any

Speaker: NA
Text: check on the sailing of merchant craft.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tlie Atlantic Ocean has perhaps never dur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the' war been quite as safe as the Indian

Speaker: NA
Text: Ocean is now, but the raider has brought the

Speaker: NA
Text: war a little closer to our part of the world,

Speaker: NA
Text: which has, by the protection of the Britisli

Speaker: NA
Text: Navy, and of our own war-ships, so long lived

Speaker: NA
Text: in a condition of peace.

Speaker: Mr BOYD
Text: I n view of the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: the British Government publish daily the

Speaker: NA
Text: names and tonnage of vessels lost on the

Speaker: NA
Text: British coast through the attacks of sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: marines, will the Prime Minister say why

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth Government cannot

Speaker: NA
Text: publish the names of vessels lost i n Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian waters, and give the public f u l l

Speaker: NA
Text: information concerning them ? Are the

Speaker: NA
Text: British Government preventing the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Governmeut from doing what

Speaker: NA
Text: they do themselves?

Speaker: Mr HUGHES
Text: I know that there is

Speaker: NA
Text: an apparent inconsistency between the

Speaker: NA
Text: action of this Government, i n connexion

Speaker: NA
Text: with the matter referred to, and the action

Speaker: NA
Text: of the British Government. A t the same

Speaker: NA
Text: time, i t must be remembered thab the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsibility of the war rests upon the

Speaker: NA
Text: I 'wish to British Government and the British A d -

Speaker: NA
Text: miralty, and not upon the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. The attitude I take up is

Speaker: NA
Text: tliat, unless and unti l we are permitted

Speaker: NA
Text: to make these statements public, I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: feel free to do so. I think that, on the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole, that is the right attitude for this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government) to adopt, although I admit

Speaker: NA
Text: quite candidly that i n all human proba-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility the first to know about these

Speaker: NA
Text: things is the enemy. For the honor-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's information, I may say

Speaker: NA
Text: that we have asked the British Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment how far we may disclose those losses

Speaker: NA
Text: which occur i n Australian. waters.

Speaker: NA
Text: CENSORSHIP .

Speaker: Mr LAIRD SMITH
Text: I wish to know

Speaker: NA
Text: from tlie Minister representing the M i n

Speaker: NA
Text: ister for Defence what are the conditions f a l l on them.

Speaker: NA
Text: under which the censorship is exercised in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia ?

Speaker: Mr GROOM
Text: Th e honorable member

Speaker: NA
Text: having informed me of his intention

Speaker: NA
Text: ask the question, I am prepared with

Speaker: NA
Text: the -following reply: -

Speaker: NA
Text: The Censorship is an Imperial establish-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, being a branch of the Imperial General

Speaker: NA
Text: Staff. The head of this branch is the

Speaker: NA
Text: Censor. War Office, London, who exercises

Speaker: NA
Text: general control over censors in all parts

Speaker: NA
Text: the world, and to whom all censors are di-

Speaker: NA
Text: rectly responsible!

Speaker: NA
Text: The general instructions for censorship are

Speaker: NA
Text: drawn up by the Imperial Authorities, and

Speaker: NA
Text: these instructions specify the establishment,

Speaker: NA
Text: qualifications necessary, 'and the

Speaker: NA
Text: onlcers employed on such work. The aims of

Speaker: NA
Text: censorship and methods of enforcing the

Speaker: NA
Text: are also laid down by these instructions.

Speaker: NA
Text: Censorship is divided into three classes:-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 and 2. Cable and Mail Censorship

Speaker: NA
Text: these branches of censorship are

Speaker: NA
Text: lated solely by instructions issued

Speaker: NA
Text: the Imperial authorities. All

Speaker: NA
Text: mation gained in the exercise of

Speaker: NA
Text: classes of censorship is forwarded di-

Speaker: NA
Text: rect to the Chief Censor, London.

Speaker: NA
Text: formation of local importance gained

Speaker: NA
Text: from the above sources is also

Speaker: NA
Text: conveyed to thc Governmental

Speaker: NA
Text: ments concerned.

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. Press Censorship -Thi s is regulated

Speaker: NA
Text: instructions issued by the Chief Cen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sor, London, as to the general

Speaker: NA
Text: censorship, by the provisions

Speaker: NA
Text: War Precautions Begulations,

Speaker: NA
Text: are based on the provisions contained the first of the horde.

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Imperial Defence of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Act, and by the expert advice

Speaker: NA
Text: naval and military authorities of the

Speaker: NA
Text: ; Commonwealth Government.

Text: MALTESE INAUSTRALIA .

Text: Wit h

Speaker: NA
Text: to reference to the Maltese who, I under-

Text: Harbor, I ask the Prime Minister what

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: -Bot h statement was i n substantial agreement

Speaker: NA
Text: reguwith that of the honorable member so fa r

Speaker: NA
Text: by as the position of these Maltese and their

Speaker: NA
Text: inforfamilies is concerned. The reverend gen-

Speaker: NA
Text: these tleman was i n Australia at the time of

Speaker: NA
Text: Intlie referendum campaign, and is perfectly

Speaker: NA
Text: aware of the circumstances which have led

Speaker: NA
Text: directly up to the present position. He knows

Speaker: NA
Text: Departthat the Governmenb at the time were

Speaker: NA
Text: forced to take certain action by statements

Speaker: NA
Text: by deliberately made for the purpose of mis-

Speaker: NA
Text: aims of leading the electors, that a horde of

Speaker: NA
Text: of the coloured people were coming into this

Speaker: NA
Text: which country, and thab these Maltese were

Speaker: NA
Text: I did not attempt

Speaker: NA
Text: Realm to justify to h i m , or to anybody

Speaker: NA
Text: of the else, the action that was taken, on any

Speaker: NA
Text: ground than 'that ' i t was forced upon us

Speaker: NA
Text: as a means of refuting what was an ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: vious and palpable calumny. What I

Speaker: NA
Text: told the reverend gentleman was this:

Speaker: NA
Text: These men are here now. We have ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: hausted every means at our disposal to

Speaker: NA
Text: get them back to Europe, and have failed.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: a transport to take them back.

Speaker: NA
Text: latest development has, of course, accen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tuated the difficulty of dealing with them.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: man could give me a definite assurance,

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: proof, bhat these men can be employed,

Speaker: NA
Text: and that they are willing to join the

Speaker: NA
Text: union, I will let them i n . That is the

Speaker: NA
Text: position. Father Bonett said that that,

Speaker: NA
Text: in fact, was the object for which the men

Speaker: NA
Text: had lived all these years, and had come

Speaker: NA
Text: out to Australia.

Text: DEPORTATION OF MR . B . M .

Speaker: NA
Text: MARTIN.

Speaker: Mr FINLAYSON
Text: the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, upon notice-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. Whether it is a fact that a Mr B. M.

Speaker: NA
Text: Martin, a resident of Queensland, was declared

Speaker: NA
Text: of Martin tried, and was he given any oppor-

Text: all posttunity to speak in his own defence?

Speaker: NA

Text: tion extend?

Speaker: Mr HUGHES
Text: Th e answers to tho

Speaker: NA
Text: honorable member's questions are as fol-

Speaker: NA
Text: low : -

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. Barthclemy Martin, a subject of an allied

Speaker: NA
Text: power, and regarded as a defaulter from its

Speaker: NA
Text: army, and in possession of Spanish, Mexican,

Speaker: NA
Text: ancl American naturalization papers, who ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rived in Australia about three years ago, was

Speaker: NA
Text: deported from Australia. Seditious conduct

Speaker: NA
Text: was one of tlie grounds which led the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Defence to order his deportation.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. Martin was not tried by any Court or

Speaker: NA
Text: autliority.

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. See answer to 2.

Speaker: NA
Text: 4. Martin was dealt with under paragraph

Speaker: NA
Text: 2 j of the Aliens Restriction Order 1915 (see

Speaker: NA
Text: Gazette of 2nd March, 1916), which authorizes

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Defence to " order the de-

Speaker: NA
Text: portation of any alien," and provides that

Speaker: NA
Text: " any alien with respect to whom such an order

Speaker: NA
Text: is made shall forthwith leave and thereafter

Speaker: NA
Text: remain out of the Commonwealth."

Speaker: NA
Text: 5. See answer to 4.

Speaker: NA
Text: MANIFESTO TO AUSTRALIAN SOLDIERS.

Speaker: NA
Text: FROM MB. W. M. HUGHES, PRIMS MINISTER

Speaker: NA
Text: OF THE COMMONWEALTH.

Speaker: NA
Text: Soldiers of Australia}

Speaker: NA
Text: After more than two years of heroic effort,

Speaker: NA
Text: the tide of battle, which so long ran strongly

Speaker: NA
Text: with the enemy, who bad been prepared for

Speaker: NA
Text: and deliberately provoked war, turns slowly

Speaker: NA
Text: but surely in our favour. The results of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Great Offensive, during which you have added

Speaker: NA
Text: fresh lustre to the glorious name of Anzac,

Speaker: NA
Text: have shown that if the Allies but press reso-

Speaker: NA
Text: lutely on, decisive victory must crown their

Speaker: NA
Text: heroic labours.

Speaker: NA
Text: But though the valour and dash of the Allied

Speaker: NA
Text: forces have pushed her legions back along a

Speaker: NA
Text: wide front, the day of decisive victory is not

Speaker: NA
Text: yet in sight. No one of you who knows the tre-

Speaker: NA
Text: mendous resources of the enemy, his courage,

Speaker: NA
Text: his determination, will say that Germany is

Speaker: NA
Text: yet defeated.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet she must be defeated.

Speaker: NA
Text: The world yearns for peace, but any peace

Speaker: NA
Text: would be but a hollow mockery, unless the

Speaker: NA
Text: great disturber of the world's peace were first

Speaker: NA
Text: beaten to her knees. Until Germany is driven

Speaker: NA
Text: headlong from France and Belgium, and de-

Speaker: NA
Text: cisively beaten on her own soil, she will never

Speaker: NA
Text: consent to the peace that the Allies want and

Speaker: NA
Text: are determined to have.

Speaker: NA
Text: In order to ensure decisive victory the Allies

Speaker: NA
Text: have decided to put every available man into

Speaker: NA
Text: the field, so that their Armies may be kept

Speaker: NA
Text: at full strength, and every man in the trenches

Speaker: NA
Text: kept fit by frequent reliefs.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Path to Victory.

Speaker: NA
Text: When you know all this, you know also that

Speaker: NA
Text: the path of victory lies stretched in front of

Speaker: NA
Text: you. You know it is on the Western Front

Speaker: NA
Text: that the crashing blow must be delivered. You

Speaker: NA
Text: know that more men are needed, and the Bri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tish Empire must supply them.

Speaker: NA
Text: France for nearly two years endured the

Speaker: NA
Text: brunt of the most ferocious batterings of the

Speaker: NA
Text: enemy. The bones of her gallant sons strewed

Speaker: NA
Text: the soil of their dear France like shells on

Speaker: NA
Text: the sea shore. She has covered herself with

Speaker: NA
Text: imperishable glory. She was never so great

Speaker: NA
Text: as in this supreme hour of her trial. Despite

Speaker: NA
Text: their great losses, her glorious soldiers still

Speaker: NA
Text: fight on with unshaken resolution, and will

Speaker: NA
Text: fight while one Frenchman, capable of bearing

Speaker: NA
Text: t and i n Eng- arms, remains alive.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now is the hour when our race must prove

Speaker: NA
Text: itself worthy of its traditions and its heritage.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is our War, Soldiers t

Speaker: NA
Text: This is Australia's war just as much as

Speaker: NA
Text: France's or Belgium's. Our liberties and our

Speaker: NA
Text: national existence are equally, nay, more, at

Speaker: NA
Text: stake. Australia must do her share. Britain

Speaker: NA
Text: has told us what she expects us to do; i t is

Speaker: NA
Text: not" inore than we can or ought to do, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed, much less proportionately than she her-

Speaker: NA
Text: self has done.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have sent overseas and have in camp in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia or in England and in the field less

Speaker: NA
Text: than three hundred thousand troops. Britain

Speaker: NA
Text: has five million under arms. I f we had done

Speaker: NA
Text: as much we should have enlisted five hundred

Speaker: NA
Text: thousand instead of little more than half that

Speaker: NA
Text: number.

Speaker: NA
Text: Voluntary recruiting has, unfortunately,

Speaker: NA
Text: proved quite inadequate to supply the necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: number of men during the past three months.

Speaker: NA
Text: Thongh voluntarism fails, Australia must

Speaker: NA
Text: not fail. Duty, honour, and self-interest alike

Speaker: NA
Text: point the path we must tread.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Spirit of Patriotism: The Duty of

Speaker: NA
Text: Upon the citizens of Australia, the freest

Speaker: NA
Text: Democracy the world has ever known, there

Speaker: NA
Text: rests a grave and solemn responsibility. Tbey

Speaker: NA
Text: are called upon to show themselves worthy

Speaker: NA
Text: of their great privileges. The sacred duty of

Speaker: NA
Text: every free man is to fight i n the defence of

Speaker: NA
Text: his country. Men ought not to wait to be

Speaker: NA
Text: compelled to do their duty, they ought rather

Speaker: NA
Text: to rush to the ranks on the first sound of.

Speaker: NA
Text: the tocsin.

Speaker: NA
Text: I t was this spirit, soldiers, that inspired

Speaker: NA
Text: you to enlist. I t was this spirit that spurred

Speaker: NA
Text: you to your great deeds on Gallipoli and i n

Speaker: NA
Text: France. I t is this spirit that now upholds

Speaker: NA
Text: you, and urges you on.

Speaker: NA
Text: Voluntarism has Failed.

Speaker: NA
Text: I had hoped that this spirit so perwasited

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian manhood that we should only need

Speaker: NA
Text: to ask for men to be overwhelmed with recruits;

Speaker: NA
Text: but during these past five months the number

Speaker: NA
Text: of men offering themselves has been steadily

Speaker: NA
Text: falling oft, and is now a mere fraction of

Speaker: NA
Text: those required for drafts.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government Proposals.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n these circumstances the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: decided that the deficiency between the number

Speaker: NA
Text: of men required and the monthly quota must

Speaker: NA
Text: be made up by compulsion. On the twenty-

Speaker: NA
Text: eighth of this month, the citizens of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: will be asked to vote " Yes " to the following

Speaker: NA
Text: question :-

Speaker: NA
Text: " Are you i n favour of the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: having in this grave emergency, the same

Speaker: NA
Text: compulsory powers over citizens i n regard

Speaker: NA
Text: to requiring their military service for the

Speaker: NA
Text: term of the war outside the Commonwealth,

Speaker: NA
Text: as i t now has in regard to military service

Speaker: NA
Text: within the Commonwealth ?"

Speaker: NA
Text: I f the citizens and soldiers of Australia ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: prove, the Government will thereafter provide

Speaker: NA
Text: that either by voluntary enlistment or by com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pulsion the regular monthly reinforcement shall

Speaker: NA
Text: be trained and sent abroad to maintain the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Army.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government consider that the number

Speaker: NA
Text: of fit single men without dependants is suffi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cient, when supplemented by voluntary recruit-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, to carry us through the war. The Go-

Speaker: NA
Text: vernment believe that i t will not be necessary

Speaker: NA
Text: to call up married men. The following classes

Speaker: NA
Text: of single men will be exempt:-

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. A l l under 21 years of age;

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. Only sons;

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. Single men who are the sole support of

Speaker: NA
Text: dependents;

Speaker: NA
Text: 4. When one or more members of a family

Speaker: NA
Text: have enlisted, the remaining members

Speaker: NA
Text: up to at least one half of the whole

Speaker: NA
Text: family, will be exempt.

Speaker: NA
Text: There will also be exemptions for the number

Speaker: NA
Text: of men requisite to carry on certain vital in-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustries.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other men who claim exemption for special

Speaker: NA
Text: reasons will have their cases heard by non-

Speaker: NA
Text: military tribunals, with appeal to a State

Speaker: NA
Text: Judge, and final appeal to a Justice of the

Speaker: NA
Text: High Court of the Commonwealth.

Speaker: NA
Text: No State to Make up any Deficiency in

Speaker: NA
Text: Free lien. the others.

Speaker: NA
Text: No State of the Commonwealth which has

Speaker: NA
Text: furnished its own quota of reinforcements by

Speaker: NA
Text: voluntary recruiting or by compulsion will be

Speaker: NA
Text: required to make up the deficiency of any other

Speaker: NA
Text: State.

Speaker: NA
Text: For the Term of the War only.

Speaker: NA
Text: The power asked for to compel military ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice abroad will be granted to the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: for the term of the war only.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's Duly to Britain and her Allies.

Speaker: NA
Text: Soldiers, i f the people of Australia vote " N o , "

Speaker: NA
Text: they encourage the enemy, they abandon you,

Speaker: NA
Text: they desert France that has shed its blood

Speaker: NA
Text: in tbe common cause, they desert Belgium,

Speaker: NA
Text: they leave .unavenged those foul outrages in-

Speaker: NA
Text: flicted upon women, children, and helpless non-

Speaker: NA
Text: combatants of the Allied nations, they repudiate

Speaker: NA
Text: the debt they owe to Britain, under tbe wing

Speaker: NA
Text: of whose mighty Navy they have lain secure

Speaker: NA
Text: and safe from all the horrors of this war. I n -

Speaker: NA
Text: deed they cover Australia with the mantle of

Speaker: NA
Text: eternal shame; the glorious name of Anzao

Speaker: NA
Text: becomes a tarnished and dishonoured thing.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia Looks to You.

Speaker: NA
Text: Soldiers of Australia, your fellow citizens,

Speaker: NA
Text: confronted with the greatest crisis in their

Speaker: NA
Text: history, look to you for a lead. Your votes

Speaker: NA
Text: are being taken first. I appeal to you who

Speaker: NA
Text: have gone out to fight our battles, who have

Speaker: NA
Text: covered the name or Australia with glory, to

Speaker: NA
Text: l i f t up'your voices and lend one mighty shout

Speaker: NA
Text: across the leagues of ocean, bidding your fellow

Speaker: NA
Text: citizens do their duty to Australia, to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Empire, to its Allies, and to the cause of liberty

Speaker: NA
Text: and vote " Y e s . "

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: W. M . Hughes, the Prime Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: .good manifesto, too.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: The honorable member's time has expired.

Speaker: Mr CHARLTON
Text: Hunter) [5.56] -

Speaker: NA
Text: I did not intend to take part in this de-

Speaker: NA
Text: bate at all, but so many references havo

Speaker: NA
Text: been made to recent happenings that I

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Text: Yes , and we then

Text: come of a member who has not 500 pence

Speaker: NA
Text: at his back i f he has to run the risk of

Speaker: NA
Text: being dragged into the Supreme Court

Speaker: NA
Text: because of some statement which he has

Speaker: NA
Text: made i n his public position ? The thing

Text: is really preposterous. I f a man makes

Speaker: NA
Text: a statement outside he takes the respon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sibility of his utterance, but in this Cham-

Text: ber an honorable member should be p r i -

Text: vileged to speak as he pleases. We have

Speaker: NA
Text: that privilege. I do not know what Sena-

Text: tor Watson will do, but I do not hesitate

Text: to say that i f I were i n his place, I ,

Speaker: NA
Text: as a representative of the people,

Text: would say what I thought was necessary

Text: if I believed the statement to be correct

Text: and i n the interest of the public, and I

Text: would never go outside to appear in a

Speaker: NA
Text: Court i n connexion with my statement.

Text: I would claim privilege every time, as I

Speaker: NA
Text: would have a perfect right to do.

Speaker: NA
Text: An HONORABLE MEMBEB - I t is very

Speaker: NA
Text: cowardly.

Speaker: Mr CHARLTON
Text: From the early

Speaker: NA
Text: days of the House of Commons every re-

Speaker: NA
Text: presentative of the people has had this

Text: privilege. I f the Government appoint a

Text: Judges to go into the matter, surely no-

Text: body can take exception to them? They

Text: flected upon Senator Watson he would

Speaker: NA
Text: carry that odium before the people f o r

Speaker: NA
Text: having made a statement i n which there

Speaker: NA
Text: was no truth . That is the position; there

Speaker: NA
Text: is no escape from i t .

Text: Withou t privilege we

Text: might as well shut up Parliament.

Text: E x a c t l y ; that is

Text: my argument.

Speaker: NA
Text: pending the Government while an inquiry

Text: of that kind is being held ?

Text: Th e Ministry are

Speaker: NA
Text: already suspended. I n a few weeks bhis

Text: moribund Government will have a dissolu-

Text: tion, and must appeal to the people. The

Text: next week. I believe that Judges, or a

Text: Judge of the High Court, - ought to be

Text: plain as to a fair appeal not being made

Text: when we appeared before the electors on

Text: movement. I know what he has done, I

Text: other hand, I know the other man also.

Text: I know that Senator Watson is an upright

Text: man, with an exemplary character, the

Text: same as the Prime Minister bears. Let a

Text: proper tribunal be appointed to sift this

Text: matter, and i f i t is found that Senator

Text: I n sanctioning an inquiry by Judges, or

Text: one Judge of tlie H i gh Court, the Go-

Text: and just in the interests of members of

Text: the two.

Text: If c would afford a splen-

Speaker: NA
Text: I wish to say a few words in regard to a

Text: question which was asked last evening, be-

Text: Minister seemed to me to be loaded. I n

Text: I n the previous week.. Senator Watson

Text: deputation. He said, " I do nofc know

Text: am alive and well, and here, yes." " On

Text: the strength of that statement," . I said,

Text: " I will tell him to come over." " Very

Speaker: NA
Text: w e l l , " said the Prime Minister, " he will

Text: take the risk." I said, " I will

Speaker: NA
Text: ask him to come." H e came oyer

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Seam mine a t Newcastle, the foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: trade of the porb having fallen off, has

Text: been slack, the mine working about two

Text: mine, but thafc they were not likely to need

Text: or any other in the Newcastle district.

Speaker: NA
Text: I wish to repeat now what I have

Text: Th e Treasurer would

Speaker: NA
Text: be superhuman who could do what you

Text: wish.

Text: I am a member of

Speaker: NA
Text: a Committee that has examined the ex-

Text: Secretary, and the Auditor-General, of

Text: reason why the Estimates should not be

Text: The y take no account

Text: T h a t has little t o

Speaker: NA
Text: member do with i t - Parliament cannot control

Text: outside. the Administration of the country whep

Text: i t does not deal with the Estimates u n t

Text: most of the money provided for therein

Text: in the year, and do without Supplv Bills.

Text: The Treasurer tells us that there will be

Text: a Supply and Tender Board.

Speaker: NA
Text: find i t difficult to understand why

Speaker: NA
Text: political parties in" the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament should be unable to drop

Speaker: NA
Text: their differences of opinion in order

Speaker: NA
Text: that a National Government might be

Speaker: NA
Text: formed to devote their energies to the

Speaker: NA
Text: i l successful prosecution of the war, as has

Speaker: NA
Text: been done i n other parts of the Empire.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n the TJnited Kingdom we find that par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties who have been opposed to each other

Speaker: NA
Text: for generations, and who have viewed

Speaker: NA
Text: each others' political ideals with hatred,

Speaker: NA
Text: dropped all their political differences at

Text: the call to arms, -and formed themselves

Speaker: NA
Text: into a National Government to prosecute

Speaker: NA
Text: the war to the bitter end. I n the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Commons, previous to the war, there

Speaker: NA
Text: was a combination of Liberals, National-

Speaker: NA
Text: ists and Labour members on the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment side numbering 398, whilst the Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: servatives i n opposition numbered 272.

Speaker: NA
Text: I n proportion to their numbers, the poli-

Speaker: NA
Text: tical parties are now represented i n a

Speaker: NA
Text: National Government of tlie TJnited

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingdom that is carrying on the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of the country i n this crisis to the

Speaker: NA
Text: satisfaction and admiration of the Em-

Speaker: NA
Text: pire. I n South Africa political differences

Speaker: NA
Text: of opinion are most marked. There is the

Speaker: NA
Text: South African party of 54 members, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Unionists of 40 members, the National-

Speaker: NA
Text: ists of 27 members, a Labour .party of

Speaker: NA
Text: 4, and an Independent party of 5.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet we learn that all these gentlemen

Speaker: NA
Text: find i t possible to see eye to eye i n the

Text: present great crisis. They dropped their

Text: gan have loyally supported the Empire

Text: servatives and 87 Liberals in the

Text: ing Dominion of New Zealand, we find

Text: dropped their political antipathies, and

Speaker: NA
Text: have formed themselves into one party f or

Text: the prosecution of the war.

Text: sons, who were fed on the premises. The

Text: Queen's H a l l which, to the uninitiated,

Text: explosive.

Speaker: NA
Text: thought that i f they made gauges for

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: The Treasurer has placed before the -

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee and the country a very

Speaker: NA
Text: candid statement of thc finances of

Text: the Commonwealth. I t is right that,

Text: the war, Australia should stand four-

Speaker: NA
Text: square to her responsibilities, and her

Speaker: NA
Text: light one. The Treasurer has been very

Text: candid, and his statement is f u l l . He has

Speaker: NA
Text: shown us that, with our ordinary obliga-

Speaker: NA
Text: -tions for services, plus the expenditure

Speaker: NA
Text: f o r the prosecution of. the war, we must,

Speaker: NA
Text: i n addition to ordinary revenue, find each

Text: year a sum ' of £6,800,000 as interest

Text: on the loans, &c. That is reckoning our

Speaker: NA
Text: war indebtedness at. the figure at which

Speaker: NA
Text: i i stands to-day. We know that that debt

Text: is going to accumulate, and consequently

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasurer's estimate of £6,800,000

Speaker: NA
Text: additional revenue required will be vastly

Speaker: NA
Text: increased; and the people of this country

Speaker: NA
Text: should be prepared f o r the increased taxa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion which must follow. I wish to deal

Speaker: NA
Text: very briefly with recent deyelopments in

Speaker: NA
Text: the political life of this country. I do

Speaker: NA
Text: They not propose to trace the history of all the

Speaker: NA
Text: happenings since the declaration of war,

Speaker: NA
Text: except to say that there was a period dur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing which I think the whole of the citi-

Speaker: NA
Text: zens of Australia had but one object in

Speaker: NA
Text: view, ' and thafc was to stand to their

Speaker: NA
Text: obligations to prosecute the war with the

Speaker: NA
Text: utmost effort of which the nation was

Speaker: NA
Text: capable. Unfortunately, that condition

Speaker: NA
Text: of affairs does not exist to-day. Whether

Speaker: NA
Text: the decision to consult the people as to

Speaker: NA
Text: the methods to be adoptedby which we

Speaker: NA
Text: should w i n the war was right or wrong-

Speaker: NA
Text: and i t is too late now to hold a post-

Speaker: NA
Text: mortem upon i t - i t is sufficient to say

Speaker: NA
Text: that the taking of the referendum divided

Speaker: NA
Text: the people of Australia into two great

Speaker: NA
Text: hostile camps. That is greatly to be re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gretted. The attitude of the party to which

Speaker: NA
Text: I belong, since i t appealed to the people

Speaker: NA
Text: for authority at the last election to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: They get duct the war, and since that authority

Speaker: NA
Text: being given to our opponents i n politics,

Speaker: NA
Text: has been to follow the Government in every

Speaker: NA
Text: measure they believed to be necessary for

Speaker: NA
Text: the prosecution of the war. For over two

Text: years the Liberal party has been the

Speaker: NA
Text: shadow following the figure, at first, while

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Fisher was Leader of the Labour

Speaker: NA
Text: party, subsequently when he was succeeded

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Hughes, and to-day when Mr.

Speaker: NA
Text: Hughes leads the present combined party.

Speaker: NA
Text: Our attitude, and the forces behind us,

Speaker: NA
Text: have been consistent in this regard

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout. But, unfortunately for the

Speaker: NA
Text: country, there has heen a family quarrel

Speaker: NA
Text: amongst those opposed to us in politics.

Speaker: NA
Text: That family quarrel has placed Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: in Buch a position that we are not now

Speaker: NA
Text: prosecuting thc war with the same unani-

Speaker: NA
Text: mity and vigour as we did before.

Text: I draw attention to

Speaker: NA
Text: the state of the House. [Quorum formed.]

Text: A s a result of this

Speaker: NA
Text: unfortunate cleavage we have to-day the

Speaker: NA
Text: Official Labour party, the Hughes party,

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Liberal party; and the Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: party and the Hughes party have co-

Speaker: NA
Text: alesced for the purpose of prosecuting

Text: the war. There has been no fusion, and

Text: no attempt at fusion. Wo have not at-

Text: tempted to put our two platforms to-

Speaker: NA
Text: gether and come to a common agreement.

Speaker: NA

Text: principles that brought me into this

Text: House, and I have no intention of doing

Text: been elected to his position by the

Text: country, and is sincere and patriotic

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal party and the forces in the coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: try behind it are prepared to put aside

Speaker: NA
Text: their individual and political ideals for

Speaker: NA
Text: the timo being, until we get the great

Text: struggle over. I t will then be time

Text: enough to see where we stand, so far as

Text: one of those who, when the recent nego-

Text: tiations were under consideration, both

Text: Becaus e you wished to

Text: kill them.

Text: know how we could carry on the go-

Text: vernment of the country. Last night I

Text: being. Some one else could play with

Text: over to the enemy. I propose to pass

Text: sent internal condition while a life and

Text: death struggle is going on. iu the other

Text: part of tho world. Ib is not credtable

Text: it, is right and fair that on a particular
